definition:
Let $K$ be a number field and let $S$ be a finite set of absolute values
of $K$, containing all archimedean valuations. The ring of $S$-integers
of $K$, usually denoted by $R_S$, is the ring:
$$R_S=\{ k\in K : \nu(k)\geq 0 \text{ for all valuations } \nu \notin S \}.$$

Notice that, for any set $S$ as above, the ring of integers of $K$,
$\mathcal{O}_K$, is always contained in $R_S$.

Let $K={\mathbb{Q}}$ and let $S=\{\nu_p,|\cdot|\}$ where $p$ is a prime
and $\nu_p$ is the usual $p$-adic valuation, and $|\cdot|$ is the usual
absolute value. Then $$R_S={\mathbb{Z}}\left[\frac{1}{p}\right]$$ , i.e.
$R_S$ is the result of adjoining (as a new ring element) $1/p$ to
${\mathbb{Z}}$ (i.e. we allow to invert $p$).
